Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Apple Q1 Fiscal Year 2025 Earnings Conference Call.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: My name is Suhasini Chandramouli, Director of Investor Relations.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Today's call is being recorded.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Speaking first today are Apple CEO, Tim Cook, and he will be followed by CFO, Kevan Parekh.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: After that, we'll open the call to questions from analysts.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Please note that some of the information you'll hear during our discussion today will consist of forward-looking statements, including, without limitation, those regarding revenue, gross margin, operating expenses, other income and expense, taxes, capital allocation, and future business outlook, including the potential impact of macroeconomic conditions on the company's business and results of operations.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: These statements involve risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results or trends to differ materially from our forecast.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: For more information, please refer to the risk factors discussed in Apple's most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K and the Form 8-K filed with the SEC today along with the associated press release.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Apple assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: I'd now like to turn the call over to Tim for introductory remarks.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Before I talk about our results I'd like to take a moment to acknowledge the devastating wildfires that impacted the Los Angeles area this month.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: From our retail teams to Apple TV+, Apple Music, Fitness Plus, Beats and more LA is home to many of our team members.
Strategic Focus Areas: Apple, Apple Music, Fitness Plus, LA

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Our thoughts are with everyone who is beginning the road to recovery.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: For our part, we are contributing to the relief efforts and we will continue to support our teams and the local community.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Today, Apple is reporting revenue of $124.3 billion for the December quarter, up 4% from a year ago, and an all-time record.
Strategic Focus Areas: Today, Apple, $124.3 billion, December quarter, 4%, year ago

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: EPS also set an all-time record of $2.40, 10% higher year-over-year.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We achieved all-time revenue records across the majority of the countries and regions we track, including the Americas, Europe, Japan, and the rest of Asia Pacific.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We also continue to see momentum in emerging markets, setting all-time revenue records in a number of markets, including Latin America, the Middle East, and South Asia, among others.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: In services, we achieved an all-time revenue record, and in the past year, we've seen nearly $100 billion in revenue from our services business.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I'm also pleased to announce that we reached a new record for our installed base with over 2.35 billion active devices.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: In October, we released the first set of Apple Intelligence features in U.S. English for iPhone, iPad, and Mac, and we rolled out more features and expanded to more countries in December.
Strategic Focus Areas: October, Apple Intelligence, U.., iPhone, iPad, December

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Now users can discover the benefits of these new features in the things they do every day.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: They can use writing tools to help find just the right words, create fun and unique images with Image Playground and Genmoji, handle daily tasks and seek out information with a more natural and conversational Siri, create movies of their memories with a simple prompt, and touch up their photos with clean up.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We introduced visual intelligence with camera control to help users instantly learn about their surroundings.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Users can also seamlessly access chat GPT across iOS, iPadOS and MacOS.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And we were excited to recently begin our international expansion with Apple Intelligence now available in Australia, Canada, New Zealand, South Africa, and the U.K. We're working hard to take Apple Intelligence even further.
Strategic Focus Areas: Apple Intelligence, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, South Africa, U.K., Apple Intelligence

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: In April, we're bringing Apple Intelligence to more languages, including French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, Japanese, Korean, and simplified Chinese, as well as localized English to Singapore and India.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And we'll continue to roll out more features in the future, including an even more capable Siri.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Apple Intelligence builds on years of innovations we've made across hardware and software to transform how users experience our products.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Apple Intelligence also empowers users by delivering personal context that's relevant to them.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And importantly, Apple Intelligence is a breakthrough for privacy and AI with innovations like Private Cloud Compute, which extends the industry-leading security and privacy of Apple devices into the cloud.
Strategic Focus Areas: Apple Intelligence, Private Cloud Compute, Apple

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Apple Intelligence opens up an exciting new frontier and is already elevating experiences across iPhone, iPad, and Mac.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We're going to keep investing in innovation and in transformative tools that help users in their everyday lives.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Let me now turn to our results for the quarter, starting with iPhone.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: iPhone revenue came in at $69.1 billion, reaching all-time iPhone revenue records in dozens of markets and regions.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Our iPhone 16 lineup takes the smartphone experience to the next level in so many ways, and Apple Intelligence is one of many reasons why customers are excited.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: With the A18 powered iPhone 16 and iPhone 16 Plus, users are getting a big boost in battery life and incredible camera experiences with camera control.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Our amazingly powerful iPhone 16 Pro models go even further with larger-than-ever displays and a pro camera system so advanced it can turn moments into masterpieces.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: In Mac, revenue was $9 billion for the December quarter, 16% higher year-over-year, driven by significant excitement around the world for our latest Mac lineup.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: The Mac is more than just a powerful tool.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: It's a launchpad to enable users to bring their best ideas and boldest creations to life.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And there are so many reasons to choose Mac, from the breathtaking performance of the M4 family of chips to the groundbreaking and growing capabilities of Apple Intelligence.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Every product in the Mac lineup offers something extraordinary, whether that's the super portable MacBook Air, the powerhouse MacBook Pro, the world's best all-in-one iMac, or the small wonder that is the Mac Mini, which is not only stunningly capable, but is our first carbon neutral Mac.
Strategic Focus Areas: MacBook Air, MacBook Pro, one, iMac, Mac Mini

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: All of this is enabled by the unparalleled power of Apple Silicon.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: iPad revenue was $8.1 billion, up 15% from a year ago, driven by strong interest for our latest products.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We love hearing from customers, who are discovering for the first time the versatility of iPad from the ultra-portal iPad Mini, built from the ground up for Apple intelligence, to the powerful M4 iPad Pro in a stunningly thin and light design.
Strategic Focus Areas: iPad, iPad Mini, Apple, M4 iPad Pro

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: iPad is there for our users whenever they need it and wherever they go and we are pleased to see so much excitement and enthusiasm for our lineup.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Wearables home and accessories revenue came in at $11.7 billion.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: With its most advanced display yet and a thinner more comfortable design, the all-new Apple Watch Series 10 is the perfect companion to help users pursue their health and fitness goals this year.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: From the powerful Vitals app to more customizable activity rings, users have an ever-increasing set of innovative health tools at their fingertips and watchOS 11.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Health innovation has long been a focus for us, and we're committed to continuing to advance this work, because we know how much it matters to our users.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We've introduced new hearing health features on AirPods Pro 2, and new sleep apnea notifications on Apple Watch are also helping users learn of a potentially serious condition that's thought to affect up to a billion people worldwide.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: During the quarter, we also brought Apple Vision Pro to even more countries, enabling more customers to discover the magic of spatial computing.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Users are enjoying incredible immersive entertainment experiences and powerful new features and enhancements to Mac virtual display.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Vision Pro is also supercharging the creative process and the incredibly talented director John M. Chu recently shared how its extraordinary capabilities helped him bring the movie Wicked to life.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Turning to services, we set an all-time revenue record of $26.3 billion for the December quarter, growing 14% from a year ago.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We set all-time records in the Americas, Europe, and rest of Asia-Pacific, and a December quarter record in Japan.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Five years since launch, Apple TV+ continues to be home to incredible storytelling that viewers love.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: There's nothing quite like the anticipation that comes when a fan favorite returns, and we were thrilled to debut the second season of Severance earlier this month.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We have so much in store for our subscribers this year with new shows like The Studio and Your Friends and Neighbors.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And we can't wait for the premiere of Formula 1 starring Brad Pitt on June 27, which will take viewers inside the sport in a truly unprecedented way.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We're excited that Apple TV+ continues to draw attention and accolades.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: To-date, Apple TV+ productions have earned more than 2,500 nominations and 538 wins.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: During the quarter, we were also excited to launch a new Find My Service that can help our users when they lose their luggage.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: For the first time, if you put an air tag in your suitcase, you'll be able to share its location information with many major airlines, so they can quickly track down your bags if they get lost.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Turning to retail, our teams went above and beyond to help customers find the perfect gift throughout the holiday season.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We also celebrated openings of new stores in China, Spain, and the U.S. and we were excited to announce plans to connect with even more customers this year by adding a fifth store in the UAE and bringing our online store to Saudi Arabia this summer.
Strategic Focus Areas: China, Spain, U.., year, UAE, Saudi Arabia, summer

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We can't wait to welcome customers to the first of several flagship store locations in Saudi Arabia that were opening beginning in 2026.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I just had the chance to visit both countries last month, and I had a great time meeting with customers and team members.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: There's an incredible energy and passion for technology in these growing markets.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Every day, I get deeply moving notes about the many ways our technology is enriching our users' lives.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I recently got a note from a customer who put his watch on his father's wrist when he feared something was wrong with him.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: The watch alerted them that the father was an AFib and they were able to get him to the hospital for potentially life-saving treatment.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Another user put his new watch on for the first time and within 15 minutes was notified of a low heart rate that led to a necessary pacemaker.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And there are so many touching notes around the profound impact of our new hearing health feature like a recent user who told me it had changed her life, allowing her to take part in conversations with her children and grandchildren.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: These are the kind of stories that remind us of how profoundly important our work is, and it drives us to innovate each and every day.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: At Apple, the future is full of promise and potential.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We're always searching across a world of possibilities, finding those places where we can do the most good and putting all of our energy and ingenuity into making something special.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: I'm going to cover the results for the first quarter of our fiscal year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We are very pleased to report an all-time high for revenue with December quarter revenue of $124.3 billion, up 4% year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We achieved all-time revenue records in the Americas, Europe, Japan, and rest of Asia Pacific and grew in the vast majority of markets we track.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Products revenue was $98 billion, up 2% year-over-year, driven by growth from iPad and Mac.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Thanks to our incredible customer satisfaction and strong loyalty, our installed base of active devices reached an all-time high across all products and geographic segments and is now over 2.35 billion active devices.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Services revenue reached an all-time record of $26.3 billion, up 14% year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We grew in every geographic segment and achieved all-time records in both developed and emerging markets.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Company gross margin was 46.9% at the high-end of our guidance range and up 70 basis points sequentially, primarily driven by favorable mix.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Products gross margin was 39.3%, up 300 basis points sequentially, primarily driven by favorable mix and leverage.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Services gross margin was 75%, up 100 basis points sequentially, primarily driven by mix.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Operating expenses of $15.4 billion landed at the midpoint of our guidance range and up 7% year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: This strong business performance resulted in all-time records for both net income at $36.3 billion and diluted earnings per share of $2.40, up 10% year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Operating cash flow was also strong at $29.9 billion, which included the impact of the $11.9 billion we paid during the quarter in connection with the state aid decision.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Now, I'm going to provide some more details for each of our revenue categories.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: iPhone revenue was $69.1 billion, roughly flat to the prior year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We grew in the majority of markets we track and reached all-time revenue records in several developed markets, including Canada, Western Europe, and Japan and in emerging markets like Latin America, the Middle East, and South Asia.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: The iPhone Active installed base grew to an all-time high in total in an average geographic segment.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We also set an all-time record for upgraders.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: According to a recent survey from Kantar during the December quarter, iPhone was a top-selling model in the U.S., Urban China, India, the U.K., France, Australia, and Japan.
Strategic Focus Areas: Kantar, December quarter, iPhone, U.., China, India, U.K., France, Australia, Japan

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We continue to see high levels of customer satisfaction in the U.S. at 96% as measured by 451 research.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Mac generated $9 billion in revenue, up 16% year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We saw strength across our lineup from the new Mac Mini to the latest MacBook Air and MacBook Pro models.
Strategic Focus Areas: Mac Mini, MacBook Air, MacBook Pro

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: This incredible performance was broad-based with double-digit growth in every geographic segment.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: With our latest advances in Apple Silicon and our fastest neural engine ever, customers are able to take advantage of the full capabilities of AI and Mac.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: The Mac installed base reached an all-time high and we saw a double-digit growth for both upgraders and customers new to the Mac.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Additionally, customer satisfaction in the U.S. was recently measured at 94%.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: iPad revenue was $8.1 billion, up 15% year-over-year, driven by the new iPad Mini and latest iPad Air.
Strategic Focus Areas: iPad, $8.1 billion, 15%, iPad Mini, iPad Air

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: The iPad installed base reached another all-time high, and over half of the customers who purchased an iPad during the quarter were new to the product.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Customer satisfaction was at 96% in the U.S. based on the latest reports from 451 Research.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Wearable's home and accessories revenue was $11.7 billion, down 2% year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Customers are excited about the new AirPods 4 and the latest hearing health features in AirPods Pro 2.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: On watch, although we face a difficult compare against the watch Ultra 2 launch last year, the Apple Watch installed base reached a new all-time high, with over half of customers purchasing an Apple Watch during the quarter being new to the product.
Strategic Focus Areas: Ultra 2, last year, Apple Watch, half, Apple Watch, quarter

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Customer satisfaction for watch in the U.S. was reported at 94%.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Our services revenue reached an all-time high of $26.3 billion, up 14% year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Services continues to see strong momentum, and the growth of our installed base of active devices gives us great opportunities for the future.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We also see increased customer engagement with our services offerings.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Both transacting and paid accounts reached new all-time highs, with paid accounts growing double-digits year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Paid subscriptions also grew double-digits.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We have well over 1 billion paid subscriptions across the services on our platform.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We remain focused on improving the breadth and quality of our services offerings, from new games on Apple Arcade to exciting new programming on Fitness Plus, and the continued expansion of features like Tap to Pay, now live in 20 markets.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Turning to enterprise, we have seen businesses continue to expand their deployments of our products and services.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Deutsche Bank launched its Mac as Choice program for the developers and also issued the latest MacBook Air as a standard computer for their entire mortgage lending division.
Strategic Focus Areas: Deutsche Bank, Mac Choice, MacBook Air

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And we're excited to see leading enterprises such as SAP leverage Apple Intelligence in the U.S., with features like writing tools, summarize, and priority notifications to enhance both their employee and customer experiences.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We also see strong demand in our emerging markets.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: For example, Zomato, a leading food ordering and delivery company in India, has deployed 1,000 of Macs across their workforce to foster innovation.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: In Vision Pro continues to see more use cases in enterprise, with Cisco's new spatial meetings delivering a fully immersive video conferencing experience for remote collaboration and learning.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Let me quickly summarize our cash position and capital return program.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We ended the quarter with $141 billion in cash and marketable securities.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We repaid $1 billion in maturing debt and decreased commercial paper by $8 billion, resulting in $97 billion in total debt.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Therefore, net cash at the end of the quarter was $45 billion.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: During the quarter, we returned over $30 billion to shareholders.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: This included $3.9 billion in dividends and equivalents and $23.3 billion through open market repurchases of 100 million Apple shares.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: As usual, we will provide an update to our capital return program when we report results for the March quarter.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: As we move ahead into the March quarter, I'd like to review our outlook which includes the types of forward-looking information that Suhasini referred to at the beginning of the call.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: The color we're providing today assumes that the macroeconomic outlook doesn't worsen from what we're projecting today for the current quarter.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: As the dollar is strengthened significantly, we expect foreign exchange to be a headwind and to have a negative impact on revenue of about 2.5 percentage points on a year-over-year basis.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Despite that headwind, we expect our March quarter total company revenue to grow low to mid-single-digits year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We expect services revenue to grow low-double-digits year-over-year.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: When you remove the negative impact of the foreign exchange headwinds I described earlier, the year-over-year growth rate would be comparable to that of the December quarter.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We expect gross margin to be between 46.5% and 47.5%.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We expect operating expenses to be between $15.1 billion and $15.3 billion.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We expect OI&E to be around negative $300 million, excluding any potential impact from the mark-to-market of minority investments, and our tax rate to be around 16%.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Finally, today our Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.25 per share of common stock payable on February 13, 2025, to shareholders of record as of February 10, 2025.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: With that, let's open to call the questions.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: We ask that you limit yourself to two questions.

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Certainly, we will go ahead and take our first question from Erik Woodring with Morgan Stanley.

Speaker: Erik Woodring
Statement: Great guys, Thanks so much for taking my questions.

Speaker: Erik Woodring
Statement: Tim, in your prepared remarks, you had noted that iPhone 16 models are selling better in markets where Apple Intelligence is available?

Speaker: Erik Woodring
Statement: And I'm just wondering if you could double-click on that comment a bit and share any other details you believe could better help us understand how Apple Intelligence is really impacting iPhone demand and/or what features you find that users are using most often already?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: The -- we did see that the markets where we had rolled out Apple Intelligence, that the year-over-year performance on the iPhone 16 family was stronger than those where Apple Intelligence was not available.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: In terms of the features that people are using, they're using all of the ones that I'd referenced in my opening comments from writing tools to image playground and Genmoji to visual intelligence and more.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: The cleanup is another one that is popular and people love seeing that one demoed in the stores as well.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We only had 2, 2.5 weeks or so during the December quarter of the second release of [18.2] (ph) and then only had the U.K. and the other English language countries for the 2.5 weeks.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so we've got just the early indications at the moment, but we were glad…

Speaker: Erik Woodring
Statement: And then, you know, if we just touch on China, obviously, in the news fairly frequently, if we set aside China Macro, which I understand is still challenging, can you maybe talk about the headwinds that that Apple faces, whether that's, you know, shifting preferences for Western technology brands in favor of domestic vendors, or is this just a function of not necessarily having Apple intelligence available with the iPhone 16, which is, you know, not necessarily helping replacement cycles.

Speaker: Erik Woodring
Statement: Just maybe double clicking on, on what you think and what you're hearing in China as a regard as it relates to the iPhone.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: If you look at our greater China revenue for the quarter, we were down 11% year-over-year.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And over half of the decline that we experienced was driven by change in channel inventory from the beginning to the end of the quarter.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And of course on the Apple intelligence side we have not rolled out in China and as we just talked about we did see better results in the markets that we had rolled out in than markets we hadn't rolled out in.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And of course, it's the most competitive market in the world.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: In terms of the macro situation, there was a fiscal stimulus or subsidy announced in very recently in January that did not affect the December quarter.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: There were some provincial subsidies in the December quarter, but the national program was announced, I believe, on January 20.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And it does cover the categories that we have products in from smartphones to tablets and PCs and smart watches up to a certain, a maximum price point.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so we do see fiscal stimulus occurring and we'll be glad to talk about what that looks like on the next call.

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from Ben Reitzes with Melius.

Speaker: Ben Reitzes
Statement: And, hey, Tim, I wanted to ask you who -- you knew this one was coming, but there's a perception that you're a big beneficiary of lower cost of compute and I was wondering if you could give your worldly perspective here on the DeepSeek situation and if you are going to, if you, if anything's happened to change your views in terms of a tailwind to margins and your ability to execute even due to the potential for cost to come down due to that development and probably what was going to happen anyway.

Speaker: Ben Reitzes
Statement: But I'd love your perspective on that and then have a quick follow-up.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: In general, I think innovation that drives efficiency is a good thing.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Our tight integration of silicon and software, I think, will continue to serve us very well.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: As you know, we do things on the device, and we do things in the private cloud and which mimics from a architectural point of view the -- what happens on the device.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And from a CapEx point of view, we've always taken a very prudent and deliberate approach to our expenditure and we continue to leverage a hybrid model, which I think continues to serve us well.

Speaker: Ben Reitzes
Statement: And then, you know, just with regard to, you know, the iPhone trajectory, do you feel like, I guess, what is -- you obviously don't talk about new products and stuff like that, but do you feel that there's a lot of room for form factor innovation in the future?

Speaker: Ben Reitzes
Statement: Or do you feel that the current lineup kind of it shows where you're going?

Speaker: Ben Reitzes
Statement: I guess without pulling punches wondering if you, you thought you know in terms of the phone innovation if there's a lot more to come and you could see the kind of current market changing a bit over the next two to three years.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I think, Ben, I think there's a lot more to come and I could not feel more optimistic about our product pipeline.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: So I think there's a lot of innovation left on the smartphone.

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from Michael Ng with Goldman Sachs.

Speaker: Michael Ng
Statement: First, it was encouraging to hear about the record for iPhone upgraders, which I think is something you haven't said for about a year now.

Speaker: Michael Ng
Statement: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you would attribute this upgrade strength to?

Speaker: Michael Ng
Statement: Has Apple Intelligence played a role in helping upgrades in the markets that you've launched in?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: If you look at iPhone, we did set an all-time record for upgraders, so we've never seen a higher level of upgraders before.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: The installed base hit a new all-time high as well.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And if you look at the 16, compared to the 15 from launch, which occurred, as you know, in September, so this is across now two quarters from September to the end of the December fiscal quarter, the 16 outperformed the 15.
Strategic Focus Areas: 16, 15, September, two quarters, September, end December fiscal quarter, 16, 15

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so I think you can conclude from that, that there are compelling reasons to upgrade.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And in the markets where we had launched Apple Intelligence, they outperformed the markets that we did not.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Yes, lots of good color there.

Speaker: Michael Ng
Statement: And then I had one about the iPad Pro and for the thinner version.

Speaker: Michael Ng
Statement: I was just wondering if you could talk about that thin form factor for the iPad Pro.

Speaker: Michael Ng
Statement: How did it help iPad sales overall and what did your kind of marketing consumer research tell you about how consumers valued that thin product form factor?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: iPad overall grew 15% for the quarter and it was more driven by iPad Air and the entry level iPad than it was the top level iPad.
Strategic Focus Areas: iPad, 15%, quarter, iPad Air, iPad, iPad

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: But overall we could not be more pleased with the iPad category growing 15%.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And probably what is most important is that over half of the sales in the December quarter went to customers who were new to the iPad.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: So that tells us that there's a good amount of customers there to attract.

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from Amit Daryanani from Evercore.

Speaker: Amit Daryanani
Statement: Maybe to start with, you folks are seeing some very robust growth trends in emerging markets right now for Apple products?

Speaker: Amit Daryanani
Statement: Can you just add a high level, just talk about the durability of growth that you see in emerging markets?

Speaker: Amit Daryanani
Statement: And then do you think the summation of these emerging markets are starting to get big enough or perhaps starting to grow fast enough that it can actually offset some of the China headwinds you're going through?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We have great results in a number of emerging markets.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And as you know from past calls, I'm particularly keen on India.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: India set a December quarter record during the quarter.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We've announced that we're going to open four new stores there.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We also, the iPhone was the top selling model in India for the quarter.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And it's the second largest smartphone market in the world and the third largest for PCs and tablets and so there's a huge market and we are -- we have very modest share in these markets.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And that's just one of the emerging markets.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Yes, maybe I'll add, Amit, that in emerging markets we're also seeing double-digit growth on the install base, both in total and for the iPhone as well.

Speaker: Amit Daryanani
Statement: And then, you know, just a question on gross margins for the March quarter.

Speaker: Amit Daryanani
Statement: You folks are guiding gross margin is flattish on a sequential basis.

Speaker: Amit Daryanani
Statement: Typically, I think it tends to be guided up a little bit, 50 basis points, so sequentially.

Speaker: Amit Daryanani
Statement: Can we just touch on like, what are the offsets of the puts and takes you see here on gross margins?

Speaker: Amit Daryanani
Statement: And Kevan, maybe you can just talked about its FX having an outsized impact in your margin profile as well in March?

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Yes, Amit, let me take that One.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: You know, as we mentioned in my remarks, we're guiding to 46.5% to 47.5%.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: So we think it's, you know, we're very pleased with that level of guidance.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: As you mentioned, there's always puts and takes.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We do think there's going to be some FX headwinds, which we talked about, that's going to affect, you know, our revenue growth as well.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: You know, it'll have an impact here on the margin, a sequential impact on margins.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: But we think that's going to be offset by favorable costs and the relative mix of services.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We also, as you know, when we move from Q1 to Q2, especially on the product side, because Q1 is such a large quarter for a products business, we do have a loss of leverage.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: So there are some puts and takes, and I think we feel good about the range.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We think it's a very, very strong guide for gross margin.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Operator, could we get the next question, please?

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.

Speaker: Wamsi Mohan
Statement: Tim, I want to follow-up on your comment about channel inventory in China.

Speaker: Wamsi Mohan
Statement: I was wondering if you could maybe address more broadly if channel inventory across your different product lines and regions?

Speaker: Wamsi Mohan
Statement: Do you feel they're elevated or out of range in any other regions?

Speaker: Wamsi Mohan
Statement: And given the clearing event that kind of happened in China, I guess in the quarter, should we think of a more normal progression quarter-on-quarter into the March quarter in China in particular, and I will follow.
Strategic Focus Areas: China, quarter, quarter--quarter, March quarter, China

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Yes, I don't want to project sales for the current quarter by region, but if you if you look at the channel inventory and look at iPhone in the aggregate, so on a worldwide basis we're very comfortable with our channel inventory position in the -- in China my point was that our channel inventory reduced from the beginning of the quarter to the end of the quarter, and that was over half of the reduction in the reported results.
Strategic Focus Areas: current quarter, iPhone, China, beginning quarter end quarter, half

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so if you look, part of the reason for that is that our sales were a bit higher than we forecasted them to be toward the end of the quarter.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so we ended a little leaner than we had expected to.

Speaker: Wamsi Mohan
Statement: And then maybe as my follow-up, your services growth has been very strong and I know you've kind of been navigating some pretty challenging regulatory burdens on the business globally.

Speaker: Wamsi Mohan
Statement: So how should investors think about maybe either a top line or margin headwind that let's say you're currently absorbing in your results that could potentially maybe reverse in a more balanced regulatory environment?

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: So I think one, I just wanted to kind of reiterate the fact that, you know, our services business had an all-time record for December quarter of 14%.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And that was a one strength that we saw across all geographic segments and also was very broad base across all of our services.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: So we have, as you know, a very broad services portfolio.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And so we do see, you know, good momentum across the board.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And as well, we continue to see increasing engagement across the customer base, across all of the service offerings, both transacting and paid accounts.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We talked about reaching all-time highs, and we have over now 1 billion paid subscriptions across the services platform.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Operator, could we get the next question, please?

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from Samik Chatterjee with JPMorgan.

Speaker: Samik Chatterjee
Statement: I guess for the first one, if I -- I mean, you had a great quarter on Macs and iPads both.

Speaker: Samik Chatterjee
Statement: And I'm just curious, in terms of if you can help us think about the sustainability of this double-digit growth that you saw in both the product lines, and more interest are also here, we are talking about Apple Intelligence sort of influencing volumes on iPhones, but any thoughts on sort of how -- what does that influence look like in terms of volumes for Macs, for example, where I think there's a lot of conversation on AI PCs, how you're thinking about the impact there?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: If you look at Mac, Mac was up 16% and on iPad, we were up 15%.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: The Mac was driven by the very strong uptake on our new products during the quarter and the continued success of the MacBook Air.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so as you know, we've launched an M4-based MacBook Pro, an iMac and a Mac Mini during the quarter.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We believe we've got the best AI PC out there for running workloads.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: The silicon in the Mac is, and it has been for several years now, designed by us and really designed for these workloads.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so I don't want to project at the category level for the future, but we're incredibly pleased with both the Mac and the iPad for the quarter.

Speaker: Samik Chatterjee
Statement: And Tim, I'm going to use your earlier discussion about India as a strong emerging market to sort of ask you about the supply chain planning there in terms of how much of the supply chain planning there that you're doing is more of a reflection of the growth expectations from that market relative to in terms of diversification of the supply chain?

Speaker: Samik Chatterjee
Statement: And how should we sort of think about that strategy in terms of that particular country?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: If you look at the manufacturing we do there, we do manufacturing both for the domestic market, and we export.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so in -- our business needs a certain economies of scale for it to make sense to manufacture in country.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so that really means that we're going to be both a use for the domestic market and an export market.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Operator, could we get the next question, please?

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from David Vogt with UBS.

Speaker: David Vogt
Statement: I'm trying to think about your commentary around Apple Intelligence being sort of a momentum driver for the iPhone business.

Speaker: David Vogt
Statement: But when I think about your kind of framework for the March quarter, if I kind of adjust for channel inventory over the last couple of years, kind of, feels like your iPhone revenue for the March quarter is going to be relatively similar to the quarter two years ago and even the quarter last year?
Strategic Focus Areas: March quarter, last couple years, iPhone, March quarter, quarter two years ago, quarter last year

Speaker: David Vogt
Statement: So how do we square kind of the momentum versus kind of the iPhone business effectively really kind of unchanged over the last couple of years?

Speaker: David Vogt
Statement: And then second, when I think about kind of the gross margin profile of the business, obviously, you've done a great job in taking gross margins up.

Speaker: David Vogt
Statement: Where do you think we sit in terms of, on the services side at least, where margins could go?

Speaker: David Vogt
Statement: It looks like the 75% margin has been incredibly successful quarter.

Speaker: David Vogt
Statement: But just trying to get a sense for where do you think this number could go over the intermediate term?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: If you look at Apple Intelligence, what my point earlier was, that markets where we had rolled out Apple Intelligence during the Q1 period performed better on a year-over-year basis than markets where we had not.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so that gives us -- it's a positive indicator that we were pleased with.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: There are many compelling reasons to upgrade.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And the other thing I would say, that I think I mentioned earlier, is that if you look at it from a launch to the end of the December quarter, and so that goes back to September, the 16 family is outperforming the 15 family.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so I think those are two good data points.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Our next round of language rollouts will be in April.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And I'll let Kevan take the gross margin question.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: So on the Services gross margin, I think maybe just stepping back a second.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Services business in general in aggregate is accretive to the overall company margin.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And one of the things, as an important reminder, is we've got a very broad services portfolio.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And those businesses have very different margin profiles.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And so I think, one, it's because of the nature of those businesses and in part also because of the way we account for them.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And so one of the big factors that drive the Services gross margins and relative performance of those different businesses within the portfolio.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: We also have the dynamic of some scale businesses like payment services, iCloud, that are actually growing.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And there, when we add incremental users, those end up being accretive to margins as well.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And so in general, what we saw in the December quarter was nice momentum across our entire services business that allows us to deliver that 75% margin at the services level.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And I think our guidance takes into consideration what we think we're going to land from a company standpoint of 46.5% to 47.5%, which again, we think is a strong guide.

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from Krish Sankar with TD Cowen.

Speaker: Krish Sankar
Statement: One, the first one for Tim.

Speaker: Krish Sankar
Statement: You had very strong Mac growth, 16% year-over-year last quarter.

Speaker: Krish Sankar
Statement: Just wondering how much of that was driven by some of the Mac silicon innovation versus a replacement cycle for Macs?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I don't know the answer to your question precisely, but I think it is a combination of these products are so compelling, the M4-based products are so compelling, that it's driving both upgrades at the double-digit level and it's driving switchers at a double-digit level.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so we're seeing both come out, and I think it's just because of the compelling products.

Speaker: Krish Sankar
Statement: And then a follow-up for Kevan on the gross margin.

Speaker: Krish Sankar
Statement: I want to ask you on the product side.

Speaker: Krish Sankar
Statement: Last quarter, you had 39.3%, which is very strong, similar to a year ago period.

Speaker: Krish Sankar
Statement: I'm kind of curious how much more levels do you have on the product side to improve the gross margin?

Speaker: Krish Sankar
Statement: Or do you think with some of the more new AI-related devices, there's more upside to gross margin from here on the product hardware side?

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: So on the product side, as you mentioned, we had pretty strong sequential improvement, 300 basis points, for the December quarter.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: That was really driven by, we talked about, favorable mix and leverage.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: As you know, in Q1, again, it's a launch quarter for many products, and so we tend to benefit from the leverage that we get from that higher volume.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: I would say, in general, our gross margin on products is driven by a number of factors.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: One of them is the various product launches that we have.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: Different products do have different margin profiles.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And so that mix does make a difference.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And in particular, what we're seeing is, for example, many of our mix is across like phone, for example, we're seeing customers gravitate towards our Pro products because of things like affordability that allows our customers to get into our best products, which have favorable gross margins.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: So we're continuing to see that trend, that impacted us in the December quarter.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: As well, I think we're in a favorable commodity environment from a cost standpoint.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And so we're benefiting from that as well in the December quarter.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And then that's going to be, as we talked about, we're going to have a foreign exchange headwind heading into the March quarter, but we figured that's contemplated in the guidance range that we gave, the 46.5% to 47.5%.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Operator, could we get the next question, please?

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from Richard Kramer with Arete Research.

Speaker: Richard Kramer
Statement: I'd like to ask about what might accelerate the pace of Apple Intelligence adoption.

Speaker: Richard Kramer
Statement: I guess do you see this simply as a question of time i.e., to launch more markets and languages or increase the percentage of installed base devices that can support it?

Speaker: Richard Kramer
Statement: Or is it a question of money, i.e., shifting R&D or marketing spend towards AI?

Speaker: Richard Kramer
Statement: And based on other prior Apple services, do you expect a sort of tipping point where adoption will go mainstream?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I do believe it will go mainstream.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I'm getting feedback from people using different features today.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And this is -- keep in mind that on the iPhone side of our business, you either have to have an iPhone 15 Pro or iPhone 16 to use Apple Intelligence.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so the -- as that base grows, I think the usage will continue to grow.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And I think -- I know from my own personal experience, once you start using the features, you can't imagine not using them anymore.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I know I get 100s of e-mails a day, and the summarization function is so important.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And of course, in April, we roll out a whole series of new languages that we had mentioned, and so the base grows further.

Speaker: Richard Kramer
Statement: And then, Kevan, one of Luca's legacies was really getting Apple to record margin levels and also maintaining very consistent pricing across the product range.

Speaker: Richard Kramer
Statement: But taking the current high levels of profitability as fairly stable, what observations might you share about price sensitivity of users and whether having a wider range of pricing across the products might unlocks potentially further market share gains or boost overall product growth?

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: I think one, I don't think we're going to really depart from what served us pretty well to now.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: I mean we always take it into consideration, looking at short-term -- comparison between the short term and the long term.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: I think we've had a pretty disciplined pricing strategy, which would serve us pretty well.

Speaker: Kevan Parekh
Statement: And I think we're going to continually kind of stick with that as far as I can tell.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Operator, could we get the next question, please?

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our next question is from Atif Malik with Citi.

Speaker: Atif Malik
Statement: How do you guys see the potential tariff impact to your product for consumer demand under Trump 2.0 you guys did find under Trump 1.0?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: We are monitoring the situation and don't have anything more to add than that.

Speaker: Atif Malik
Statement: And Tim, as a follow-up, there is a lot of discussion on agentic AI, the use of agents.

Speaker: Atif Malik
Statement: Do you guys see the upgraded series expected in April as something that will, let's say, be the killer application among the suite of features that you have announced in Apple Intelligence?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I think the killer feature is different for different people.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: But I think for most, they're going to find that they're going to use many of the features every day.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And certainly, one of those is the -- is Siri, and that will be coming over the next several months.

Speaker: Suhasini Chandramouli
Statement: Operator, could we please get the last question?

Speaker: Operator
Statement: Our last question is from Ben Bollin from Cleveland Research Company.

Speaker: Ben Bollin
Statement: Tim, I'm interested in your thoughts and how you would have us think about the average useful life of these devices in the wild.

Speaker: Ben Bollin
Statement: And in particular, curious, if you look at the strength you saw in fiscal ‘21 and how that might support accelerated refresh opportunity into the future?

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: Ben, I think it's different for different types of users.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: I mean you have very early adopter kind of users that are very quick to jump on the latest technology that upgrade very frequently.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And then you have people that are on the entire opposite side of that barbell.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And most people are between those two points.

Speaker: Tim Cook
Statement: And so I do think there were lots of units that are sold during the COVID period of time, and it's a huge opportunity for us as a company to -- for more than one of the product categories.
